prompt:
What is a transfer of electrons?

1 Answer
Dec 28, 2015


Transfer of electron in chemistry is the process by which an atom "hands over" one or more of their electron


According to current theories dating mainly the 19-20th centuries, the world is made up of atoms.

Atoms in general are unstable when in single form, except noble gases, e.g. Helium.

In order to "solve" their instability issue, atoms combine.

There are mainly two types of Bonds, the name given for these combinations: Ionic and Covalent bond (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Covalent_bond).

In the former, we have a distortion of the orbital towards the strongest one, "negativity", whereas in the latter we have a "equal" sharing.

In the ionic bond we say the electron was transferred, notwithstanding it does not really happen.

What happens is that the electron(s) will stay closer to one nucleus, e.g. H-Cl (Hydrogen chloride, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen_chloride), in the case mentioned, the electronegativity, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronegativity, of Cl is much higher, thus the hydrogen "loses" its only electron, if it loses at all, it will be just a proton, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen

Ionic bonds is in general for metals, whereas coval
output:
ent bonds are for nonmetals and for molecules. The concept of transfer applies only to the ionic bond.

For covalent bonds, we don't use the concept of "transfer" because we don't consider it as such. We talk about polar bonds, e.g. in H2O, oxygen is more negative than the hydrogen atom, but they "share" the electrons. We also talk about non-polar, e.g. CH4 methane, where all the C-H bonds have equal electronegativity.

The transfer is just a way of describing what happens in an ionic bond. We could say it's a simplification of the real events, although it doesn't really describe what happens (electrons don't move).

I hope this answers your question. If not, please comment on my answer and I will try to improve it. Thanks. Hope this helps.

> What is the justification, if any, for making a comparison operation
> available, and then defining it as meaningless?
> It's not meaningless. It is just defined such that two independently
> access values may or may not be equal. This is very similar to the way
> floating point works; it shouldn't be that surprising. That is:
>     A := F'Access;
>     B := A;
>     C := G'Access;
>     D := C;
>     E := F'Acesss;
>     if A = B then -- Must be true.
>     if C = D then -- Must be true.
>     if A = C then -- Must be false.
>     if B = D then -- Must be false.
>     if A = E then -- May be either true or false.
>     if B = E then -- May be either true or false.

OK, I'll agree with you that
output:
this is a reasonable way to define equality.
It's certainly consistent with how other types of pointers are defined in
Ada.  But the reason that the Ada designers went ahead and defined it in
the first place has always puzzled me.  There are some good reasons to not
allow pointer equality, namely that it can make pointer aliasing more
likely, thereby making program analysis harder.  (In fact, the Ada
definition of "=" for task discriminants allows them to be compared for
equality even though they are pointers.)  I've never heard a convincing
argument as to why "=" should be allowed at all for access types.  In my
experience, the main use of pointer equality is in C implementations of
hash tables.  Is there another reason?

            -- Brian

physiology and psychology of stress

Define the concept of stress?

Solution Preview

Let's take a closer look. I also attached an article, which discusses different theories of stress. I also attached a sample article written in APA format and another APA resource for future reference.


1. Define the concept of stress?

One way to define stress is "a state of bodily or mental tension resulting from factors that tend to alter an existent equilibrium" (Britannica Concise Encyclopedia, n.d .). However, many theories of stress have been proposed (see attached article), which define the concept of stress based on their theory.

For example, Hans Selye (1985) defined stress as ""nonspecific" in that the stress response can result from a variety of different kinds of stressors and he thus focused on the internal aspects of stress" (cited in Cordon, 1997). In fact, Selye (1956) developed a three stage stress model including:

(a) Alarm reaction is an initial stage of lowered resistance ...

Solution Summary

Defines the concept of stress and explains the physiology and psychology of stress. References and supplementary information on stress are also provided.<|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>
output:
Human:Describe the physiological effects of stress?

Stress has a wide range of physiological effects on the body. For example,

1. It activates the sympathetic nervous system (SNS), causing an increase in heart rate and blood pressure. This helps the body prepare for the 'fight or flight' response by diverting blood away from the digestive system to vital muscles.

2. The pituitary gland releases the hormone adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which stimulates the release of cortisol, a stress hormone that increases glucose availability to meet energy demands.

3. The hypothalamus releases corticotropin-releasing factor (CRF), which stimulates the pituitary gland to release ACTH, which then prompts the adrenal glands to secrete stress hormones such as adrenaline and noradrenaline. These hormones increase breathing rate and blood sugar levels, preparing the body for intense physical activity.

4. The adrenal cortex produces aldosterone and renin-angiotensin systems, increasing sodium retention and potassium excretion, which in turn raises blood pressure. This can help maintain cardiovascular function during periods of stress.

5. Stress can cause changes in immune function, such as reduced lymphocyte proliferation and natural killer cell activity, leading to increased susceptibility to illness and infection.

In summary, stress can have significant physiological effects on the body, impacting multiple systems including the cardiovascular, endocrine, and immune systems. Chronic or prolonged stress can have long-term negative impacts on health.

Reference:
Selye, H. (1956). The stress of life. McGraw-Hill Book Co., Inc.
Cordon, J. M. (1997). Stress management: A comprehensive guide to the theories and techniques. Jones & Bartlett Learning. APA Format

---

### Physiological Effects of Stress

Stress elicits a series of complex physiological responses that prepare the body for the "fight or flight" response. When stress is perceived, it triggers several key physiological processes:

1. **Activation of the Sympathetic Nervous System (SNS)**: 
   - The SNS responds by increasing heart rate and blood pressure. This diverts blood flow away from less critical areas such as the digestive system to vital muscles, enhancing physical readiness (Selye, 1956).

2. **Release of Cortisol**:
   - The pituitary gland releases Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (

You can also use MutationObserver instead of DOMAttrModified event. It's more powerful and works everywhere DOMAttrModified works (I think). But for simplicity of explanation I chose DOMAttrModified event. Check this thread on StackOverflow for more information on difference between MutationObserver and DOMAttrModified event. You can find an example of using MutationObserver in this answer. Also check documentation here for more info.

Note: According to documentation, DOMAttrModified is deprecated. So if you don't care about supporting old browsers, MutationObserver is your best bet. If you need to support old browsers, you may need to use DOMAttrModified, or use some library like jQuery or Zepto.js that will abstract away cross-browser issues. If you need support for older versions of IE, you'll need to find a polyfill for MutationObserver. See this thread for more info. Also check this article on MDN. It says MutationObserver is supported in IE11. If that's true and you don't need to support older versions of IE, you should definitely go for MutationObserver. Here's a good thread on SO that explains the difference between DOMAttrModified and MutationObserver. For simplicity of explanation, I used DOMAttrModified event in my code sample above. So please keep this in mind when using this example.

Another note: DOMAttrModified is fired only for inline styles. If you change styles using CSS classes, you'll need to use MutationObserver. See this question. Also see this answer for another alternative to MutationObserver and DOMAttrModified event.

Also note that MutationObserver is still not supported in iOS Safari. As per this link, iOS Safari does not support MutationObserver. prompt:
Michelson-Morley experiment

Aim of the Michelson-Morley experiment: The Michelson-Morley experiment was done to confirm the presence of hypothetical medium called ether.

Therefore, one question should be there what was ether? Yes, I have used “was ether” not “is ether”. Let us discuss why?

As we have already discussed in earlier articles that there is nothing like absolute rest. Thus the scientists in the 19th century assumed that our universe is filled with hypothetical medium called ether. Ether was supposed to be transparent and highly elastic.

The main objective of this Michelson-Morley experiment was to check the presence of this medium called ether. The aim was supposed to be fulfilled by measuring the velocity of the earth with respect to the ether. If earth is supposed to be propagating through the stationary ether with a uniform velocity and if a beam of light is sent from source to observer towards the direction of the motion of the earth, then it should take more time if sent through the opposite direction. If this time difference can be measured then velocity of earth with respect to ether can be measured.

Experimental arrangement of Michelson-Morley experiment: Continue reading “Michelson-Morley experiment”

output:
**Given an incomplete code snippet for a Python function that calculates the factorial of a given number `n` using recursion, fill in the missing parts to make the function fully operational. Also, implement a simple validation mechanism that ensures that the input value of `n` is a non-negative integer before proceeding with the computation. If `n` is negative or not an integer, the function should raise a ValueError with an appropriate message.**

```python
def factorial(n):
    """
    Calculate the factorial of a given non-negative integer n recursively.
    
    Args:
    n (int): A non-negative integer whose factorial is to be computed.
    
    Returns:
    int: The factorial of the given number n.
    
    Raises:
    ValueError: If n is not a non-negative integer.
    
    Example:
    >>> factorial(5)
    120
    >>> factorial(0)
    1
    >>> factorial(-1)
    Traceback (most recent call last):
        ...
    ValueError: Input must be a non-negative integer.
    """
    # BEGIN SOLUTION
    if not isinstance(n, int) or n < 0:
        raise ValueError("Input must be a non-negative integer.")
    elif n == 0:
        return 1
    else:
        return n * factorial(n - 1)

# Function to check the correctness of the factorial function
def check_factorial():
    test_cases = [5, 0, -1, "abc", 3.14, 7]
    expected_results = [120, 1, None, None, None, 5040]

    for i, test_case in enumerate(test_cases):
        try:
            result = factorial(test_case)
            if result == expected_results[i]:
                print(f"Test {i + 1} passed: Factorial({test_case}) = {result}")
            else:
                print(f"Test {i + 1} failed: Expected {expected_results[i]}, got {result}")
        except ValueError as e:
            if expected_results[i] is None:
                print(f"Test {i + 1} passed (exception): {e}")
            else:
                print(f"Test {i + 1} failed unexpectedly: {e}")

# Uncomment the following line to run the check function
# check_factorial()
```

Note: The `expected_results` list includes `None` at positions where a `ValueError` is expected to be raised.

Sacred Texts  Classics  Index  Previous  Next 

Section 2

2. What is this other place and how it is accessible?

It is to be reached by those who, born with the nature of the lover, are also authentically philosophic by inherent temper; in pain of love towards beauty but not held by material loveliness, taking refuge from that in things whose beauty is of the soul- such things as virtue, knowledge, institutions, law and custom- and thence, rising still a step, reach to the source of this loveliness of the Soul, thence to whatever be above that again, until the uttermost is reached. The First, the Principle whose beauty is self-springing: this attained, there is an end to the pain inassuageable before.


The guiding thought is this: that the beauty perceived on material things is borrowed.


Now, what is this that gives grace to the corporeal?


We ask then is soul, of itself, a thing of beauty: we find it is not since differences are manifest, one Soul wise and lovely, another foolish and ugly: soul-beauty is constituted by wisdom.

The question thus becomes, "What principle is the giver of wisdom to the soul? and the only answer is "The Intellectual-Principle," the veritably intellectual, wise without intermission and therefore beautiful of itself.

But does even this suffice for our First?


Next: Section 3<|endoftext|><|endoftext|>

Bark damage to eastern redbud



I have an Eastern Redbud, the wind broke off 2 large branches, is there anything I can put on the tree to protect it from the elements as the bark is torn away.




The bark of a tree is the external vascular system that carries water and nutrients vital to a tree’s survival. Therefore any damage to a tree’s bark can have potentially fatal consequences. What is the extent of the bark damage? If the area of torn bark is more than 25% of the cirucumfrance of the branch or trunk, then you may need to consult an arborist.

If the bark damage is relatively small, then you can probably clean up the wound yourself. The key is to faciliate the tree to callous around the wound properly. Therefore, do not put any products onto the wound. With a sharp knife, carefully remove all the loose bark to the point where bark is sound and firmly attached. Make sure the knife has been disinfected (you can dip it in rubbing alcohol or household bleach and dry it thoroughly before cutting). Do not remove more bark than absolutely necessary, and do not to cut into the inner bark. Then leave it to the tree to do the rest.

For further information on tree bark damage, take a look at:

Identifying Damage

To find a certified arborist, start here:



Good luck!<|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>
output:
What are the symptoms of a diseased Eastern Redbud tree and how can I treat it?


Eastern redbud trees (Cercis canadensis) can suffer from several diseases including Verticillium wilt, leaf spots, canker, and powdery mildew.

Here are the symptoms for each of these common redbud diseases:
1. Verticillium Wilt - This fungal disease causes wilting, browning, and defoliation of branches. Over time, the tree will begin to decline.
2. Leaf Spots - Caused by several different fungi, leaves will develop brown or purple spots on them.
3. Canker - Caused by a variety of fungi, this disease creates sunken lesions or cankers on twigs and branches, which can girdle stems and cause dieback.
4. Powdery Mildew - This disease is caused by a fungus, and creates a white, flour-like substance on the surface of leaves.

There are some general practices that can help control these diseases.
- Good sanitation practices such as raking fallen leaves and disposing of debris from around the tree can eliminate fungal spores that spread disease.
- Pruning infected branches, but be careful to avoid damaging the bark. Prune during dry weather, and disinfect pruners between cuts with a 10% solution of household bleach (one part bleach to nine parts water).
- Provide proper cultural care to reduce stress. Water the trees deeply, mulch around them to retain soil moisture, and fertilize only when necessary.

If the disease persists, you might consider using fungicides as a last resort. However, many fungicides must be applied preventatively and won't work once the plant is infected. Always follow the manufacturer's instructions for rates and timing when applying chemicals.

You should also consider contacting a professional arborist if the problem is severe or continues despite your efforts to manage it. They can provide a diagnosis and treatment plan specific to the problem your tree is experiencing.

Please note that in some regions, certain pesticides might not be approved, and it would be best to check with your local cooperative extension service or garden center for advice on what chemicals are available and legal to use in your area. 

Remember, preventing disease through good horticultural practices is always preferable to treating a sick tree. 

It's important to note that in some cases, it might be best to replace a severely diseased tree rather than attempting to treat it.

Always check with your local agricultural extension office for specific recommendations
